conclusion: The potential difference between the upper and lower plates is V, and V is constant.
The distance between the plates is d.
Initially, a metal plate with thickness l is stacked on the lower plate.
The lower plate and the metal plate are at the same potential, say 0.
The upper plate is at potential V.
The space between the upper plate and the metal plate has a thickness of d-l.
The electric field in this region is E1 = V/(d-l).
The particle P is stationary in this region, meaning the upward electric force balances the downward gravitational force.
Let the charge of the particle be q and its mass be m.
The electric force is Fe1 = |q|E1 = |q|V/(d-l) upwards, and the gravitational force is Fg = mg downwards.
From equilibrium, |q|V/(d-l) = mg.
|q|V = mg(d-l).
When the metal plate is quickly taken out, the distance between the plates becomes d.
The potential difference between the plates is still V.
The electric field in the space between the plates is now E2 = V/d.
The electric force on the particle is Fe2 = |q|E2 = |q|V/d upwards.
The gravitational force is still Fg = mg downwards.
The net force on the particle in the upward direction is Fnet = Fe2 - Fg = |q|V/d - mg.
According to Newton's second law, the acceleration of the particle is a = Fnet/m = (|q|V/d - mg)/m = |q|V/(md) - g.
Substitute |q|V = mg(d-l) from the initial equilibrium condition: a = mg(d-l)/(md) - g = g(d-l)/d - g = g - g(l/d) - g = -g(l/d).
The acceleration is -g(l/d) in the upward direction, which means the acceleration is g(l/d) in the downward direction.
